docs.lead_paragraph: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan on Friday helped launch a national campaign opposing the health care overhaul and other government policies, portraying them as a threat to religious freedom.

headline.print_headline: Dolan Says Obama Policies Threaten ‘Sacred Liberties’

docs.abstract: Cardinal Timothy M Dolan helps launch national campaign, Fortnight of Freedom, opposing the health care overhaul and other government policies of Pres Barack Obama, portraying them as threats to religious freedom.
docs.snippet: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan on Friday helped launch a national campaign opposing the health care overhaul and other government policies, portraying them as a threat to religious freedom.

docs.lead_paragraph: How do hospitals and doctors arrive at the fees they charge? The not-so-simple answer is that it depends on the medical provider and the insurance company, and what sort of deal the provider has negotiated with their insurer.

headline.seo: Navigating the Labyrinth of Medical Costs - Your Money
headline.main: Getting Lost in the Labyrinth of Medical Bills
headline.print_headline: Getting Lost in the Labyrinth of Medical Bills

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column notes that there is no standardized pricing system for hospital services, and that patients can pay widely divergent fees for identical procedures; holds that pricing is established based on the market power of a given insurance company and hospital, and the reimbursement agreements they ultimately reach.
docs.snippet: How do hospitals and doctors arrive at the fees they charge? The not-so-simple answer is that it depends on the medical provider and the insurance company, and what sort of deal the provider has negotiated with their insurer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers say Oregon’s lottery system for granting health insurance has made it the best place to study the costs and benefits of the federal health care law.

headline.seo: Oregon Study Reveals Benefits, and Costs, of Insuring the Uninsured
headline.main: Oregon Study Shows Benefits, and Price, for Newly Insured
headline.print_headline: Oregon Study Shows Benefits, and Price Tag, for Newly Insured

docs.abstract: Researchers following tens of thousands of Oregonians find that gaining insurance under state's lottery system makes people feel healthier, happier and more financially stable; Oregon Health Study has won academic attention because of the distinct nature of the state’s health-insurance lottery; by assigning coverage randomly, Oregon gave researchers more confidence that they had teased out the true effects of insurance, and had not been fooled by other differences between the insured and the uninsured.
docs.snippet: Researchers say Oregon’s lottery system for granting health insurance has made it the best place to study the costs and benefits of the federal health care law.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the nation awaits the Supreme Court's ruling on challenges to the health care law, Americans continue to report that they struggle to pay for medical care. A quarter of Americans report problems paying medical bills in the past year, and about 60 percent say they've ''cut corners'' to avoid health care costs, according to the May tracking poll conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
docs.abstract: Bucks blog cites Kaiser Family Foundation survey finding that a quarter of Americans reported problems paying medical bills in the last year, and about 60 percent say they've cut corners to avoid health care costs. (M)
docs.snippet: As the nation awaits the Supreme Court's ruling on challenges to the health care law, Americans continue to report that they struggle to pay for medical care.     A quarter of Americans report problems paying medical bills in the past year, and about...

docs.lead_paragraph: BATAVIA, Ohio -- The tumor grew like a thick vine up the back of Eric Richter's leg, reminding him every time he sat down that he was a man without insurance. In April, when it was close to bursting through his skin, he went to the emergency room. Doctors told him it was malignant and urged surgery. His wife called every major insurance company she found on the Internet, but none would cover him: His cancer was a pre-existing condition. In desperation, the Richters agreed to pay half their hospital bill, knowing they could never afford it on their combined salaries of $36,000 a year.

headline.main: For Those Already Ill, Huge Stake in Court's Ruling on Health Care Law

docs.abstract: No other group of Americans faces higher stakes in the impending Supreme Court ruling on the Affordable Care Act than those with pre-existing conditions, who are guaranteed coverage under the law. Photos (M)3
